case_name: Private bus owners v. State of U.P.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 182 and 183 of 1954 were filed under article 132 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 182 and 183 of 1954. Appeals under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeals from Judgment and Order dated 17th November 1953 of High Court of Allahabad in Civil Miscellaneous Writ No. 414 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order, dated the 17th November, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad in Civil Miscellaneous Writ No. 414 of 1953,

facts.text: Appellants have been carrying on business of plying motor vehicles as stage carriages on hire on Bulandshahr-Delhi route for a number of years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in these two analogous appeals, along with many others, have been carrying on the business of plying motor vehicles, as ,stage carriages on hire, on the Bulandshabr-Delhi route from a number of years past.

facts.text: Running of vehicles regulated by Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 including permits by Regional Transport Authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The running of these vehicles has been regulated so long by the Motor Vehicles Act of 1939 which provides, inter alia, for granting of driving licences, the registration of vehicles and exercising companytrol over transport vehicles through permits granted by Regional Transport Authorities.

facts.text: Section 42(3) of Motor Vehicles Act exempts transport vehicles owned by Central or Provincial Government from permits unless used in connection with business of Indian State Railway.

anchor.surface_text: Section 42 3  of the Act exempts transport vehicles, owned by or on behalf of the Central Government or the Provincial Government from the necessity of obtaining permits unless the vehicles were used in companynection Path the business of an Indian State Railway.

facts.text: After 1947, Government of U.P. started running own buses on public thoroughfares, first as competitors then to exclude private operators.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, that some time after 1947 the Government of U. P. companyceived the idea of running their own buses on the public thoroughfares. They first started running buses only as companypetitors with the private operators but later on they decided to exclude all private bus owners from the field

facts.text: Transport Authorities cancelled permits of private operators and refused new permits to achieve state monopoly.

anchor.surface_text: and establish a companyplete State monopoly in respect to the road transport business. They sought to achieve this object by calling in aid the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act itself. ... The Transport Authorities, in furtherance of -this State policy, began cancelling the permits already issued to private operators and refusing permits

facts.text: Private bus owners filed petitions under article 226 in Allahabad High Court against illegal use of Motor Vehicles Act by UP Government.

anchor.surface_text: Upon this, a number of private bus owners filed petitions in the Allahabad High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for appropriate relief, by way of writs, against what was described as the illegal use of the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act -by the Government of U. P.

facts.text: Full Bench of five judges held section 42(3) conflicts with article 14 as it discriminates in favour of state buses.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions were heard by a Full Bench of five Judges and four judgments were delivered ... A majority of the judges expressed the opinion that the State, purporting to act under section 42 3  of the Motor Vehicles Act, companyld number discriminate against other persons in their own favour and that the sub- section, in so far as it purports to exempt State Transport buses from the obligation to obtain permits for their use, companyflicts with article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: All judges held nationalisation not possible by executive order without legislation justifiable under article 19(6).

anchor.surface_text: All the judges companycurred in holding that nationalisation of an industry was number possible by a mere executive order without appropriate legislation and such legislation would probably have to be justified under article 19 6  of the Constitution.

facts.text: U.P. Road Transport Act (Act II of 1951) passed and became law on 10th February 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this pronouncement of law, the State Government ... sought the assistance of the Legislature and the U. P. Road Transport Act  Act II of 1951  was passed and became law on and from the 10th of February, 1951.

facts.text: By notification dated 25th March 1953, UP Government declared stage carriage services on Bulandshahr-Delhi route exclusively by State.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated the 25th of March, 1953, the U. Government published a declaration in terms of section 3 of the Act, to the effect, that the State carriage services, among others, on the Bulandshar Delhi route, shall be run and operated exclusively by the State Government.

facts.text: Notification on 7th April 1953 set out scheme for operation on these routes.

anchor.surface_text: A further numberification issued on the 7th of April following set out what purported to be a scheme for the operation of the State carriage services on these routes.

facts.text: Two appellants and 106 other private bus owners filed writ petitions under article 226 before Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the two appel- lants as well as several other private bus owners numbering 106 in all, who plied transport buses on these routes, presented petitions under article 226 of the Constitution before the High Court at Allahabad

facts.text: High Court Division Bench dismissed writ petitions on 17th November 1953.

anchor.surface_text: All these writ petitions were heard by a Division Bench of the High Court companysisting of Mukherji and Chaturvedi JJ. By two separate but companycurring judgments dated the 17th of November, 1953, the learned Judges repelled all the companytentions of the petitioners and dismissed the writ petitions.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. October 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUKHERJEA J.-

facts.text: Court held U.P. Road Transport Act 1951 violates article 19(1)(g) as prohibition not justified as reasonable restriction under article 19(6) as it stood then.

anchor.surface_text: our companyclusion is that the legislation in question which violates the fundamental right of the appellants under article 19 1  g  of the Constitution and is number shown to be protected by clause  6  of the article, as it stood at the time of the enactment, must be held to be void under article 13 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Court held Act deprives appellants of interest in commercial undertaking without compensation, violating article 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore that in these circumstances the legislation does companyflict with the provision of article 31 2  of the Constitution and as the requirements of that clause have number been companyplied with, it should be held to be invalid on that ground.

facts.text: Court held Act does not violate article 14.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the appellant cannot make any grievance on this score and that the statute does number offend against article 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Bulandshahr-Delhi route is part of Grand Trunk Road, public highway existing since 15th Century A.D.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the Bulandshahr-Delhi route is a part of the Grand Trunk Road which is a public highway. ... There can be numberdispute that the Grand Trunk Road which, as a public highway, has been in existence since the 15th Century A. D.

holdings.text: The U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951 violates Article 19(1)(g) as the total exclusion of private operators from road transport business is not a reasonable restriction under Article 19(6) as it stood prior to the 1951 amendment, lacking materials to justify it in public interest.

anchor.surface_text: our conclusion is that the legislation in question which violates the fundamental right of the appellants under article 19 1 g  of the Constitution and is number shown to be protected by clause  6  of the article, as it stood at the time of the enactment, must be held to be void under article 13 2  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public has anterior right to ply motor vehicles for hire on highways incident to passage; Act inflicts prima facie violation; no evidence of reasonableness or public interest benefit; causes immediate hardship without compensation; pre-amendment 19(6) requires justification unlike post-amendment monopoly clause.

holdings.text: Citizens have a fundamental right under Article 19(1)(g) to carry on business of plying stage carriages for hire on public highways, as this is incident to the common law right of passage which extends to modern vehicular traffic.

anchor.surface_text: Once the position is accepted that a member of the public is entitled to ply motor vehicles on the public road as an incident of his right of passage over a highway, the question is really immaterial whether he plies a vehicle for pleasure or pastime or for the purpose of trade and business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Highway dedication implies right to all usual traffic including modern motor vehicles; MV Act regulates but does not create right; US franchise doctrine inapplicable in India; agrees with Madras HC.

holdings.text: The U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951 deprives appellants of their interest in a commercial undertaking without compensation, violating Article 31(2).

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore that in these circumstances the legislation does conflict with the provision of article 31 2  of the Constitution and as the requirements of that clause have number been companyplied with, it should be held to be invalid on that ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interest in business is property; prohibition deprives it, equivalent to acquisition; Art 31(1) and (2) read together; cites Subodh Gopal and Dwarkadas; not mere deprivation without acquisition.

holdings.text: The U.P. Road Transport Act, 1951 does not violate Article 14 as the classification creating state monopoly is reasonable and bears rational relation to legislative object.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore that the appellant cannot make any grievance on this score and that the statute does number offend against article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Monopoly inherently classifies state separately; rational for welfare state objectives; discretion under s.3 guided by Motor Vehicles Act permit rules; mere differentiation not arbitrary.

holdings.text: The right to use public highway for trade is not an easement or property in that sense; contention untenable.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak put forward another and a somewhat numberel argument that the right of the appellants to use a public highway for purposes of trade is in the nature of an easement and as such can be reckoned as property in law companysequently there has been a deprivation of property by the impugned legislation in this sense also. This companytention seems to us to be untenable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's novel argument rejected outright; abandoned in argument.

holdings.text: Whether 'restriction' under Article 19(6) includes total prohibition not decided.

anchor.surface_text: although in our opinion the numbermal use of the word restriction seems, to be in the sense of limitation and number extinction, we would on this occasion prefer number to express any final opinion on this matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed arguendo; unnecessary as fails reasonableness test anyway; cites dictionaries, Gopalan obiter.

holdings.text: Whether the Act violates Article 301 not decided, as unnecessary after holdings on Articles 19 and 31.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the fact that we have declared the Act to be unconstitutional on the two grounds mentioned above, we do number companysider it necessary to record our decision on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter discussion of possible arguments, Australian precedents; indicates points for legislature.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Packard v. Banton 1 , Sutherland J. observed as follows The streets belong to the public and are primarily for the use of the public in the ordinary way. Their use for purposes of gain is special

precedents.cited_proposition: Streets belong to the public and are primarily for public use in ordinary way; use for gain is special and extraordinary and may be prohibited or conditioned
precedents.cited_holding: The streets belong to the public and are primarily for the use of the public in the ordinary way. Their use for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary and generally at least may be prohibited or conditioned as the Legislature deems proper.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was approved in Frost v. Railroad Commission 1 , and again in Stephenson v. Binford 3 , where Sutherland J. practically reiterated his observations in the previous case as follows It is a well established law

precedents.cited_proposition: Approval of doctrine that highway use for gain is special and extraordinary, subject to legislative prohibition or condition

anchor.surface_text: and again in Stephenson v. Binford 3 , where Sutherland J. practically reiterated his observations in the previous case as follows It is a well established law that the highways of the State are public property that their primary

precedents.cited_proposition: Highways are public property, primary use private, use for gain special and extraordinary, legislature may prohibit or condition
precedents.cited_holding: It is a well established law that the highways of the State are public property that their primary and preferred use is for private purposes and that their use for purposes of gain is special and extraordinary which generally at least the Legislature may prohibit or condition as it sees fit.

anchor.surface_text: The cases referred to above were numbericed by the Allahabad High Court in the Full Bench decision of Motilal v. Uttar Pradesh Government 1 , and two of the learned Judges constituting the Full Bench expressed their opinion

precedents.cited_proposition: American doctrine of exceptional user for highways not applicable to English or Indian law

precedents.citation: C. S. S. Motor Service v. State of Madras 2

precedents.case_name: CSS Motor Service v State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Public has right to use highways for trade including motor transport; no franchise doctrine in India; state holds roads in trust
precedents.cited_holding: The true position then is, that all public streets and roads vest in the State, but that the State holds them as trustees on behalf of the public...

precedents.citation: Municipal Corporation of the City of Toronto v. Virgo 1

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Municipal Corporation of the City of Toronto v. Virgo 1 , Lord Davey while discussing a statutory power conferred on a Municipal Council to make bye-laws for regulating and governing a trade made

precedents.case_name: Municipal Corporation of Toronto v Virgo
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between prohibition/prevention of trade and regulation/governance; regulation implies continued existence
precedents.cited_holding: there is a marked distinction to be drawn between the prohibition or prevention of a trade and the regulation or governance of it...

precedents.citation: A. K. Gopalan v. The State  2

anchor.surface_text: the case of A. K. Gopalan v. The State  2 . The question for consideration in that case was the constitutional validity of the Preventive Detention Act and one of the contentions raised by the learned counsel

precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions imply rights still capable of exercise, presuppose substratum of freedom; distinction between restriction and deprivation
precedents.cited_holding: The use of the word restrictions... seems to imply... that the rights guaranteed by the Article are still capable of being exercised...

precedents.citation: Lokanath Misra v. The State of Orissa  1

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa, High Court in the care of Lokanath Misra v. The State of Orissa  1  accepted this view and made a distinction between regulation and restriction.

precedents.case_name: Lokanath Misra v State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Restrictions may amount to total prohibition; distinction between regulate and restrict

precedents.citation: Cooverjee v. The Excise COMMISSIONER, etc.  2

anchor.surface_text: a decision of this Court in Cooverjee v. The Excise COMMISSIONER, etc.  2  where the point for consideration was the validity of the Excise Regulation I of 1915.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reasonableness of restrictions depends on nature of business and conditions; state may prohibit illegal/immoral/injurious trades
